Switching banks costs money and it is unlike switching one's electricity bill. Who pays the piper? Is it the bank that pays? The Central Bank advocates switching. Is it the customer who pays? Will the bank pay the bill on a substantial mortgage as switching can cost a substantial amount?

#MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	119	First
column2: I will respond to Senator Burke's question. Yes
column3: the Central Bank has calculated that 21% of mortgage holders would have savings if they switched
column4: which is quite a high figure. To encourage switchers
column5: there was a campaign late last autumn and there another from about March up to April of 2015 to encourage people to switch. A person with 20 years gone on 25 year mortgage who is dealing with the same crowd at very small money will not switch. There is a kind of an inertia in the system. Unless the savings are significant
column6: people will not break with their traditional bank and that needs to be taken into account as well. Since we started talking to the banks about these issues
column7: many of them are now prepared to pay the switching costs. The new lender
column8: the bank being switched to
column9: is prepared to pay the switching costs. There are different offers across the banks. In talking to constituents
column10: there are serious offers in the system which can save serious money and the receiving bank will pay the switching fee. Will Senator Horkan remind me again of his question?

column1: #GerryHorkan	unknown-#GerryHorkan-party	unknown-#GerryHorkan-dob	unknown-#GerryHorkan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	120	Did the banking sector lobby the Minister or his officials about this legislation?

#MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	121	No
column2: I have had no personal lobbying from the banks. I know from contacts with the Department that the banks are concerned about this legislation. That is to be expected. To my knowledge
column3: they have not gone into the specifics of their concerns. Some of those concerns came through in my Second Stage speech. I put it to Senator Conway-Walsh that it is not true to say that the actions taken by me and my Department have not had results. They have had very strong results in some banks
column4: such as AIB. Deputy McGrath quoted the rates
column5: which are not much more than 3%. I think one can now get a mortgage from AIB for something like 3.25% or 3.3%. The rates here are getting into a space where they can compare with what is happening in some European countries. They are certainly at the bottom. AIB is not the only bank that is doing this. Other banks have various offers. PTSB is moving to a loan-to-value system whereby a customer pays a higher rate on a 90% mortgage than on a 50% mortgage. If I have headroom because of the equity in my house beyond the level of my mortgage
column6: I am a lower risk. The banks are pricing for risk. This suits some people but not others. It is not true to say there has been no movement. There are outliers that have moved on new lending to new mortgage holders but have not moved on their historic or legacy mortgages. That is the difficulty. This is now a new issue. The programme for Government provides that the Central Bank and the Competition and Consumer Protection Commission
column7: having due regard to their respective remits
column8: will work "to set out the options for the Government in terms of market structure
column9: legislation and regulation to lower the cost of secured mortgage lending". Perhaps the committee should add the Competition and Consumer Protection Commission to its list of invitees. As the authority with responsibility for competition
column10: it might have a particular perspective on many of these issues
column11: which relate to competition. In general terms
column12: I am simply giving my position on the matter. I do not disagree with the fundamental principle of what the Senator is saying
column13: which is that variable interest rates seem to be too high in the cases of certain mortgages and we should continue to bring those rates down.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	122	Is the Minister happy with the behaviour of the banks in this regard?

#MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	123	Of course I am not.

#RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	124	That is what I am trying to get at. I acknowledge that there have been some shifts which have had a positive impact. We would not be here today to discuss this Bill if the banks were doing what they are meant to do and if the Central Bank was doing what it is meant to do in line with its consumer protection role. I find it quite amazing that the Central Bank is refusing extra powers
column2: or does not want extra powers. I will ask representatives of the Central Bank questions about that matter when they come in.

column1: #MichaelNoonan	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-party	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-dob	unknown-#MichaelNoonan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	125	The difference between Deputy McGrath and me lies in how we want to achieve what is
column2: in effect
column3: a common purpose. I believe that if we can get new entrants into the market and if we can have more competition between the existing people who are offering mortgages and new entrants
column4: that will push interest rates down. Deputy McGrath is frustrated about how long it is taking some lenders to bring their rates down. He is advocating that we legislate to force rates down. The objective is the same.

column2: the Minister is under-estimating the ability of people to switch to other banks. I refer in particular to people who are in arrears. Could the Minister give me an opinion on the impact of quantitative easing on the Irish banks?

I would like to give the Senator a considered written response on this complex matter
column2: rather than giving an ad lib response here from memory.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	128	Okay. I thank the Minister.

#JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	129	I thank the Minister and his officials for attending this meeting. I want to underline my own views in so far as supporting this Bill is concerned. Individuals and families out there are suffering greatly because of the attitude of the banks to providing assistance to solve problems between banks and borrowers. Some of them are unhelpful to a degree. It is almost impossible for some people
column2: depending on their status
column3: etc.
column4: with the banks
column5: to deal with them. This problem is still the same. The banks refer people very quickly to the courts. As I said earlier
column6: as legislators we should go down to see some of those eviction courts. They are outrageous. People are not given an opportunity to defend themselves or explain their cases. The various initiatives that have been taken
column7: such as house purchases by voluntary housing agencies and the mortgage-to-rent scheme
column8: are just not working. The banks are not playing ball. They are favouring new borrowers who are coming in because such cases involve dealing with new sets of figures on a new page. They are not willing to assist borrowers on their books who are in really deep trouble. Until they are driven to the point where they are forced to deal with such borrowers
column9: we will continue to have this problem with the banks. We can imagine what it is like to deal with sub-prime lenders as they are just outrageous in their behaviour and their treatment of people. In my opinion
column10: the State was more than good to the banks when it bailed them out and gave them an opportunity to continue in the marketplace. This was done because it was decided the banks were essential in terms of the availability of money. The behaviour of the banks does not show any sign of change. As the banks are getting back on their feet
column11: they are even more aggressive and have no consideration for people. That is certainly what I am finding when I speak to people who are dealing generally with the banks. The manner in which evictions are coming about is an outright disgrace. The way people are treated when they end up in one of those courts is an outright disgrace. The banks are taking people's houses even though those people have done their utmost to work with the banks to try to keep their houses. It appears that the legislative system and all of us in this House have failed. The banks have got up off their uppers and are back at the same game again. They are treating people in an abominable fashion. I cannot stand over their activities. We will take it up with the banks and the Central Bank when they come in here. No one is assisting consumers in this area. The Central Bank's consumer protection efforts are not working for people. Like other members
column12: I am dubious about what we are told about switching accounts. People cannot switch their accounts unless they have the muscle to do so. Otherwise
column13: they are locked into their banks and no other bank is interested in them. New entrants into the market will show no interest whatsoever in someone who is in difficulty. Therefore
column14: customers are at the mercy of the banks they are with. The banks show no mercy. That is the awful disgrace of this. As they rebuild their balance sheets
column15: the people who are most marginalised and affected by this are being shown no mercy whatsoever. I have to put that on the record.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	148	I have one question. I have welcomed the Bill previously. In particular
column2: I welcome the intention to take any amendments or alterations that would enhance the Bill in any way. My question relates to vulture funds. I am rather concerned about mortgages
column3: including variable rate mortgages
column4: that are being bought up by vulture funds. Will this Bill give those affected any assurance in terms of rate caps? Will the Bill cover them? Earlier
column5: Deputy McGrath referred to regulated and unregulated categories. What category do such mortgages come under? Are they captured in this Bill?

column1: #MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	149	This is an important issue. There is a gap in the existing legislation around credit servicing. Many of the vulture funds that bought loan books are not directly regulated in Ireland. However
column2: they must appoint an intermediary
column3: which is regulated
column4: that is to say
column5: a credit servicing firm. Pepper is probably the best-known example. The legislation could only apply to regulated entities and
column6: therefore
column7: it would apply to the intermediary. All contact from a customer in respect of a mortgage is with the intermediary. I have argued that the actual owners of the loans should be regulated and I gather Sinn Féin holds a similar view. Currently
column8: they are not and I believe that is a deficiency. This Bill will apply to regulated entities and
column9: therefore
column10: it will apply to the credit servicing firm with which the customer has all contact. Another body of work remains to be done to bring all the funds within the ambit of Central Bank regulation. Currently
column11: they are not. I have argued that the owners of the loans make all the ultimate decisions on those loans. If there is a decision on interest rate policy
column12: accepting or restructuring of a mortgage or a decision about going down the enforcement and legal routes
column13: then the decision is made not by the intermediary but by the owner of the loan. However
column15: the owners are not required to be regulated under the Consumer Protection (Regulation of Credit Servicing Firms) Act 2015. That gap has to be bridged first before we can bring the funds into this legislation. The legislation does cover the credit servicing firm

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	150	My question relates to mortgage rates. It is of no use having that relationship with the intermediary under this Bill. Am I correct? Would it have any impact

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	160	I circulated a briefing note earlier but I will not go through it because we are under a little time pressure. We began this campaign two years ago. At that stage
column2: Irish mortgage rates were 1.9 percentage points higher than average eurozone interest rates. There was no justification for that at all. Today
column3: two years later
column4: Irish mortgage rates are 1.6 percentage points higher than those in other eurozone countries. While mortgage rates have come down
column5: they have come down throughout the eurozone and not just as a result of our campaign
column6: although I would like to believe the campaign we have been running for two years has resulted in the 1% reduction in the nominal rates in Ireland. A good part of the reduction is attributable to quantitative easing
column7: as mentioned earlier. Rates have decreased across Europe but the gap has hardly moved at all. That is completely unjustified. Over the two years
column8: a person on a mortgage of €200
column9: 000 has already paid approximately €6
column10: 000 more than he or she should have. He or she will continue to pay at a rate of €3
column11: 000 per year for the next number of years while he or she has the mortgage. The payments will reduce as the capital is paid off. There is a huge charge being imposed on ordinary Irish families as a result of these interest rates. There are two separate aspects to this Bill. They are separate but equally important. The first part concerns section 7
column12: which prohibits discrimination against existing borrowers. If the Houses decide the rest of the Bill is unconstitutional or undesirable
column13: it does not stop them passing section 7. I hope the whole Bill can be passed. Section 7
column15: would be a huge step forward
column16: however. It is the section that makes sure lenders offer the same rates and incentives to existing customers as to new customers. What has happened in the market is that Allied Irish Banks and Ulster Bank offer existing customers the same rate as new customers. When they compete
column17: they bring the rates down for everybody but the other banks
column23: have introduced completely new lower rates for new customers and just tell existing customers they cannot avail of them
column24: or they keep all their rates high and compete by giving incentives
column25: such as 2% cash back. We are talking about the new business rate having fallen to 3.5% or whatever it is
column26: but many customers of Bank of Ireland and Permanent TSB are currently paying at a rate of 4.5%. As mentioned on numerous occasions
column27: there are customers of Danske Bank paying at a rate of 4.95%. If section 7 were passed
column28: it would be helping very many people. The other aspect is equally important. We have been working on this for two years and have got almost nowhere. As Deputy Michael McGrath has said
column29: I would much prefer if the banks had responded and if this legislation were not needed. I would be a free market capitalist. I want to see markets working but I am not an ideologue. If the markets are not working
column30: I want to see the State intervening to make them work.This market has not worked. People are being put in a very difficult position and the Central Bank says it is nothing to do with it
column31: let competition resolve it. Competition will not resolve it. I have heard the Minister say that competition benefits all bank customers. It does not benefit the 46
column32: 000 people who are customers of vulture funds or the customers of Bank of Ireland who are on 4.5% who cannot switch. We are hoping Frank Mortgages will start lending. If it does
column33: it will lend 80% loan to value mortgages to people on 3.5 times income. It will be a very small niche market lender and people who have a bad credit record
column34: who have 90% loan to value will not get any benefit at all from that sort of competition. They are just the highlights. I will ask Stefan Goor to say a bit about his situation.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	163	We did diligent research on mortgages. At the time we got a 60%-80% loan to value mortgage at a particular rate. Shortly after we took out the mortgage that rate was cut but we did not receive a reduction in our payments. This seemed contrary to the general understanding of variable rate mortgages. We queried it with the broker who also seemed surprised and was not familiar with that scenario but the bank in question suggested that this was available only to new customers. Since we took out the mortgage there have been four cuts
column2: totalling 0.6% and we are currently paying a €100 per month more than a customer who would take out the identical mortgage today. Over the term of the mortgage we will be paying approximately €30
column3: 000 more than somebody who got an identical mortgage today. This is only a comparison between our mortgage and someone with the same lender who took an equivalent mortgage. If we compare it with the eurozone average that Mr. Burgess spoke about we are paying almost €100

column6: as I was in the fortunate position of starting a company with some colleagues

column9: which was dismissed and we are currently in the Financial Services Ombudsman
column10: FSO
column11: dispute process but that is a very long and time-consuming process and many people would not have the time or be able to spare the effort to do it. Section 7 is very important and would save many people from this unfair scenario. I thank the committee for the opportunity to raise this and the Fair Mortgage Rates Campaign and Mr. Burgess in particular for representing so many mortgage customers.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	164	Mine is not the worst scenario. column3: from memory
column4: AIB and Bank of Ireland were charging 3% and 3.25%. That rate increase on my mortgage made a 20% increase in my monthly payment. As if things were not tight enough

column6: repossession proceedings were issued because of the arrears despite the arrears being small and decreasing. The final smack in the face was the court charge of €1
column7: 200 imposed on my mortgage account despite the registrar's throwing out the case against the bank and not awarding costs to either party. I did not receive a letter stating that the account was being charged. The €1
column8: 200 is on the loan principal
column9: which amounts to €1
column10: 800 over the term of the loan. Having the ability to increase the cost of a product with little justification other than we can and we will is a truly unique business to be in. This leaves a very large portion of the mortgage market at the mercy of the existing lender to extort when it sees fit. If I walk up to someone in the street and demand €50 from that person criminal charges could follow. When a bank writes to a customer and extorts an increase in the lending rate nothing happens. The word "extort" is accurate
column11: it means the practice of obtaining something
column12: especially money
column13: through force or threats. Apart from physical harm
column14: there are few threats greater than losing one's home or one's home being at risk. The basic nature of a consumer is to shop around. Few people buy from the person who is too expensive. column15: the figures are fluid but one thing is for sure: tens of thousands of mortgage customers are stuck where they are. Being stuck with a mortgage lender who squeezes one is like wearing concrete shoes. Recently I have moved three of my five utility bills because it was free
column17: saved me money and I could. The emphasis is on "I could". Other banks offer better deals than the one I have but I am firmly stuck. The proposition of competition to deter overcharging lenders might work if everyone had good credit records
column18: better wages and met the now stringent criteria set down by the banks
column19: all of which suit the demands of the lender
column20: a far cry from their historical standards. Despite having 60% loan to value

That rules out a huge part of the mortgage customer base because of reduced income
column24: increased living expenses and a list of other factors that tips the scales to the lender. If a customer like me with 60% LTV cannot move there are new levels of bias at work. The Central Bank estimates that 21% of borrowers
column27: could save money by switching to a new lender. What it does not say is how many borrowers actually can switch. An article states that only 38 people switch every month
column28: a tiny fraction of the mortgage market.I am one of them. I could switch to five different lenders that are cheaper than my existing lender
column29: saving me between €45 and €100 per month
column30: but none will touch me. A letter from Permanent TSB in 2012 stated "I want to make it clear that I don't believe that permanent tsb has performed to an acceptable standard in recent years." column31: 000 variable rate customers over the course of a year and a half. I rang the bank shortly after receiving this letter and asked whether I would get a refund on the over-charging since it was sorry. There was a graveyard silence on the phone. I will now deal with help from the Government at the time. The mortgage interest supplement was a quick political injection to help struggling mortgages and was
column33: means tested. Not much came from banks. In fact
column34: the only thing that came from banks was restructuring; some forbearance
column35: by which I mean that it will bide its time; threatening letters; interest rate hikes; and a waiting game until increased house prices gave the banks back equity to threaten people with repossession.  The Minister claimed this Bill was unconstitutional and that there was no need for it. Why is the can constantly kicked to the customer to bear the brunt of the bill to fix things that were mostly not their doing? A headline in the Irish Independent asks why banks have been so reluctant to reduce variable mortgage rates and the simple answer is that banks charge high rates because they can and are allowed to. It is not complicated to understand that they will not reduce their rates because the banks make millions more with high rates. column40: pensions and insurance are regulated. In fact there are few financial products that are not regulated or have not been regulated in the past. Bank interest rates are not regulated. column3: that there are natural or fair rates? I know he says he would not stick to an exact rate but does he think
column4: having examined all the European rates
column5: there is a rate that would be fair and reasonable?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	178	The average rate being charged across the EU is a reasonable indication of what is a fair rate
column2: what I would call a fair base rate for mortgages. There is however
column3: no doubt about it that it is very difficult for a bank in Ireland to actually repossess a home. There is not a huge sanction for people who do not pay their mortgage. A 90% loan-to-value is far more risky to a bank. In the UK a 90% mortgage is about 1% more expensive than a 50% mortgage. It looks to me as if there should be a risk factor of about 1%
column4: or somewhere around that
column5: going from a 50% loan-to-value up to a 90% loan-to-value. I would work on the current rate
column6: which is about 2%
column7: and I would raise it for higher
column8: riskier loans.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	179	The Central Bank has made new regulations and guidelines that are supposed to make the switching easier. Has Mr. Burgess seen any positive effect of those moves at all?
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	180	No. On switching
column2: the Central Bank brought in great regulations some years ago about switching current accounts because if one switched for example
column3: from Bank of Ireland to AIB there were problems if the old bank did not co-operate
column4: such as direct debits or standing orders not going through. There were all sorts of issues. The switching code put a requirement onto the old bank to co-operate. In switching mortgages
column5: however
column6: there is no requirement for the old bank to co-operate. A person could go in to the old bank with the cheque from the new bank for the outstanding mortgage amount of €326
column7: 000 and then that person is finished with the old bank. The only real problem and difficulty for the switching of mortgages lies with the credit procedures of the new bank and there is also the legal paperwork etc. There is also the general inertia - there are a lot of borrowers who could save money by switching
column8: and they do not do it. I have not decided if I should have sympathy for those people. While it is okay for me and I would be quite happy and comfortable with switching
column9: somebody else might not be comfortable going through that process and they just stay. I have spoken to some people who have no idea and they do not understand they are being overcharged. I tell them they are paying 1% more than they should be. One person paying a mortgage of €200
column10: 000 asked me how much was 1% of that. I was very shocked at that. I assumed that everybody knew that 1% of €200
column12: 000 and that would be the amount to pay but he did not understand that.

column2: those whose loans have been restructured or those whose loans are in arrears. Is that Mr. Burgess' experience of this?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	188	Absolutely. As far as I know
column2: no bank will take on a new customer from another bank if the customer owes more than 80% of the value of the house.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	189	Yes.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	190	There are people who are in negative equity who seek to switch but they have no chance of it at all.

#RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	191	And is it likewise in terms of arrears?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	192	Arrears are a complete no-no for five years after the arrears. Mr. McNally made the point that part of the reason he was in arrears was because of the high rates and now because of the arrears he cannot switch. It is really a double whammy. He is a prisoner of Permanent TSB. He is on a low loan-to-value and he has cleared the arrears but no bank will touch his loan. They just look at the Irish Credit Bureau record and if there is a mark that says a person was in arrears within the last five years then that is it and there is no further discussion. The banks do not need to know what a person's income is or why they were in arrears - that is just it.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	193	There has been much talk about negative equity and arrears
column2: which are all negative terms
column3: but there are a lot of things that happen that are not negative but which mean a person cannot switch. For example
column4: if somebody has children then child care costs must be factored in or - like me - a person might become self-employed. Even changing jobs can preclude a person from being able to switch.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	194	So one is stuck. With regard to quantitative easing
column2: I have grave concerns about what happens when the European quantitative easing stops. I do not think that people fully understand the extent of the quantitative easing and how that has been played. It has almost been put under the radar. It is propping up the whole system which is extremely vulnerable. What does Mr. Burgess believe will happen when quantitative easing ends? It has to at some point
column3: when the ECB rates go back to normal levels. Has Mr. Burgess carried out any assessment on what that would mean for mortgage rates?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	195	No
column2: that would probably be beyond my pay grade but over the last two years the ECB rate itself has fallen by only 0.15%. Two years ago it was 0.15% and now it is zero. While it has fallen by 0.15% rates have fallen by far more than that because with quantitative easing the banks are full of money. They have nobody to lend it to
column3: or they will lend it at whatever rates they can get. I would be concerned that when quantitative easing stops and when mortgage rates rise - and if we do not fix this problem before the ECB rate starts to rise again - one can be quite sure that the banks are going to pass on every interest rate rise. Mr. Goor thought he was taking out a variable rate mortgage but KBC seemed to think that variable was only upwards. Mr. Goor could have fixed at the time and could have had the benefit of fixing
column4: but he now has the worst of both worlds.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	196	The significant point is that I do not think that customers taking out a mortgage now
column2: in this sort of scenario
column3: realise that they are not getting the variable rate that is advertised. A person takes out a variable rate mortgage loan assuming its movement will be linked to the cost of funds
column4: the competition etc.
column5: but it is not. The variable rate is at the bank's discretion.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	197	What effect might the first-time buyer scheme have on mortgage rates? #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	198	It had not occurred to me that the scheme might have an influence on mortgage rates. I was concerned about the 80% cut-off because at 80% people
column2: generally speaking
column3: pay an interest rate of about 0.2% to 0.5% lower. The 80% cut-off would have forced people to borrow 80% when a 79% mortgage would be cheaper. I am glad it is being brought down to 70%
column4: which I read in The Irish Times today. That is good. It will stop people taking out excessive mortgages.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	199	I would like to expand that point about the drop in the loan-to-value ratio down to 70%. Consider somebody who is buying a house at €400
column2: 000. Under current Central Bank rules and without any exemptions being in place they would need a deposit of €58
column3: 000 but somebody who had a loan-to-value ratio of 70%
column4: would already have savings of €120
column6: 000 of that could come from the help-to-buy scheme. Would the witness acknowledge that this drop in the loan-to-value ratio is providing a grant of €20
column7: 000 into the back pockets of people who can nearly double the amount of savings that are required under the Central Bank's rules?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	200	There are two ways of looking at it. On the one hand I believe that people should be encouraged to save and put a deposit together. By and large I support the Central Bank's rules. The overall 80% is a good idea as is the exemption for first-time buyers
column2: that is
column3: the 90% for first-time buyers up to €220
column4: 000 and the various exemptions.I am not a fan of the Central Bank but I believe it has got this right. I have mixed views on the first-time buyers grant. I would prefer if the Government was not interfering with the market
column5: but 12% of the sale price of new houses goes on VAT so I view the 5% as almost a partial refund of the 12%. I do not have the same big problem with that as do other people. The €600
column6: 000 ceiling appears to be mad and way too high. I would probably reduce it to €300
column8: which is a different way of answering the Deputy's question.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	201	In fairness
column2: it is for another day and another topic. We will see what is in the Finance Bill on that measure in the next couple of hours. To return to the issue at hand
column3: I commend the Fair Mortgage Rates Campaign. It has done sterling work in raising this issue in a focused
column4: concentrated way. I was glad to be invited to some of the campaign's events and I appreciate the advice it has given us in the past. As Deputy Michael McGrath acknowledged
column5: there are a number of key people. Obviously
column6: many people have been on the receiving end of being fleeced by interest rates
column7: but a number of prominent individuals
column8: particularly in the media
column9: such as Charlie Weston and others have continued to raise this issue. Hopefully
column10: all of this
column11: including Deputy Michael McGrath's Bill and my Bill in 2015
column12: has created some pressure on some of the lenders
column14: but some remain stubbornly on a higher rate. The presentation is excellent and succinct
column15: and gives us the data in the condensed pack that are required. The fact that the banks are charging too much and that certain people cannot switch is well established. Now
column16: we must figure out what to do about it. What is before us is the direct intervention - the determination of a market failure and the subsequent intervention by the Central Bank. With that in mind
column17: and with regard to the legislation presented by Deputy Michael McGrath and following what the Government has said or not said today
column18: does the campaign have any suggestions to the committee as to how the Bill could be strengthened and on whether it needs to be strengthened or otherwise? For example
column19: the appeals process has been raised. It has been stated
column21: that there is not an appeals process for every mechanism or body. Does Mr. Burgess have views on where we should seek to strengthen the Bill

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	202	I would like the entire Bill to be passed. There might be some minor issues. It states: "In setting a variable interest rate for a group
column2: class or category...". I would delete the word "variable". In setting a rate
column3: whether it is fixed or variable
column4: I do not wish to see just good variable rates
column5: but long-term fixed rates as well. I would certainly feed in some things such as that. On section 7 on the prohibition of discrimination against existing customers
column6: I do not know if anybody is arguing with that or if it must be checked with the ECB. I do not know if there could be a constitutional challenge to it. Is there any way to get that through as an emergency measure and then let us see the arguments in the Supreme Court about the constitutionality of the other provisions and whether the Central Bank wishes to approve it? That alone
column7: and there are only approximately 20 words in the section
column8: would be a huge help to many people and it would answer many of the points the Central Bank and the Minister make with regard to competition affecting all customers. That would mean the competition would be helped. That is one point. I had not thought of the appeals process until Senator O'Donnell raised it. There is probably a natural justice issue but I do not know enough about the area to know whether it is standard in legislation. I certainly would not object to it in any way. If Senator O'Donnell thinks it is a good idea
column9: it probably is.

He can look back on the record. What if the Central Bank sends out a signal to say in effect
column2: "Let them do whatever they want and give us the power

column1: #MichaelMcGrath	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-party	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MichaelMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	205	I thank Mr. Burgess
column2: Mr. Goor and Mr. McNally for appearing before the committee today. I thank the campaign group for all the work it has done over the last few years. It started with the Permanent TSB issue and the rates of over 6%
column3: which affected Mr. McNally. I thank Mr. McNally and Mr. Goor for sharing their personal stories. They are representative of many thousands of others who are affected by high variable rates. There is an onus on us to act and I believe we have made a good start. There has been some progress. Some of it is attributable to the campaign's work and the pressure in the Oireachtas
column4: which in turn forced the Minister to meet the banks and raise the issue. It had not even been on the agenda until all of us worked collectively to get it there. I have some brief questions for Mr. Burgess. The issue he highlights
column5: the discrimination between existing customers and new customers
column6: is a key one. Is that particular to Ireland? In Europe fixed rates are far more common
column7: with many customers on long-term fixed rates. However
column8: that discrimination undoubtedly exists. Perhaps the Central Bank already has the power to deal with that under the consumer protection provisions
column9: but I am not sure. If all of the rates in the market were around 3% to 3.5%
column10: where AIB is positioned currently
column11: would legislation such as this be warranted? Will he give us an idea of the cost of funds the banks are currently enjoying in the market? They do not get all of their money from the ECB; it is a combination of wholesale funding
column12: deposits and some ECB money. Mr. Burgess is something of an expert on this issue. What is the cost of funds the banks typically face now?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2016-10-20 00:00:00	Central Bank (Variable Rate Mortgages) Bill 2016: Discussion	206	I do not believe it is the practice across Europe to force banks to treat existing customers the same as new customers. The UK is the market I probably know most about
column2: as I keep an eye on what is happening there. It has standard variable rates and high standard variable rates but it has a very active switcher market. Where people are on variable rates in most eurozone countries and in the UK they can switch. The existing mortgage rates might be higher but there probably is no need to introduce legislation in those countries. The problem is quite specific to Ireland. Negative equity
column3: mortgage arrears and restructured mortgages mean people cannot switch so existing customers must be treated fairly.If mortgage rates decreased to 2.5% or 3% and people could switch
column4: there would be less of a need for the legislation. Tomorrow
column5: one of the vulture funds could decide it wanted to charge 10%. Mr. McNally knows what it is like for a bank to increase its rate to 6.5% over a few months while other banks are charging 3%. There is nothing a mortgage holder can do. Mr. McNally attended the permanent tsb AGM and complained about it.

column10: they are very profitable.
